chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the net present value of a given investment based on its required rate of return.

Before we start solving, we must first list down the given values that we will use:


| Project cost|$63,000 | 
|--|--| 
| Annual cash flow|$11,700 | 
| Duration|9 years | 
| Required return|8% | 
| |20% |

For the first rate of return of $8\%$ we will use a present value annuity factor to determine the present value of $\$1$ at that given rate and duration of $9$ years.

For this, the present value factor is $6.2468879$.

Substituting the values to the formula in Step 2, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=(\$11,700 \times 6.2468879)-\$63,000\\
&=\$10,088.59
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value at a required rate of return of $8\%$ is $\$10,088.59$.

For the second rate of return of $20\%$ we will use a present value annuity factor to determine the present value of $\$1$ at that given rate and duration of $9$ years.

For this, the present value factor is $4.0309665$.

Substituting the values to the formula in Step 2, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=(\$11,700 \times 4.0309665)-\$63,000\\
&=-\$15,837.69
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value at a required rate of return of $20\%$ is $-\$15,837.69$.

As we can see from the values that we computed, a rate of return of $8\%$ is profitable since its NPV is positive while the investment at $20\%$ rate of return gained a negative NPV which makes it highly unprofitable.

This means that if the company were to choose, they should choose the $8\%$ required rate of return.

Substituting the known values to the formula for NPV in Step 2, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
0&=\left[\$11,700\times\dfrac{1-(1+r)^{-9}}{r}\right]-\$63,000
\end{aligned}$$
